a very interesting concept indeed and while it is in development I do notice one major flaw with the prototype: it only accommodates the hand. In the real world, your entire arm can move without directly affecting the hand and while human intuition would tell your arm to stop while touching something in the virtual world in reality your arm could keep moving and apply more pressure to your hand as your virtual hand moves further into the object. In the real world there's nothing on your arm telling you to stop pushing against a rock or pulling on some taught rope and while your hand might feel pressure from said rock and the fingers would stop you from grabbing the object more than the object itself your arms isn't restricted or the rest of your body for that matter.

In short, I hope companies like this are striving to develop a continuous suite for VR like in the movie and book because that would actually allow the user to fully interact with a virtual world properly to the point where no movement or at least very few can bypass the rules of the virtual world any more than they could the real world.

Imagine: This, but a full body suit. You want to pick up a virtual piece of paper? Little to no resistance. A virtual 20-pound weight, though? It could actually feel like you're picking up a 20-pound weight. Just imagine: home gym sets would become much more widely accessible, not only in terms of cost, but also in space. If you are playing an fps, you could actually feel the weight of your guns, the punch of recoil. You could feel the resistance the gun puts up if you miss the magwell when reloading, you could actually feel the magazine in your hand. You could feel the bullets hit. The possibilities are really endless. Once something like this tech as a full body suit becomes readily available and costs come down to a relatively feasible level, that right there would be the point where VR becomes the standard modus of interaction for a wide variety of applications. Imagine this: you just applied for a new job, and you got accepted! Congrats, we'll be sending you your company-issue interface suit shortly. We request that you refrain from using it for non work-related applications while on the clock. I think I might have a novel on my hands...

I was lucky enough to have had a chance to play with haptic joysticks about 12 years ago in a university research lab. I got to try a consumer device (Novint Falcon) and an industrial device. I still remember that in one of the demo’s (I think even the Falcon demo, the industrial device was waaaay better still) it actually felt like I was pushing my hand through sand, even though I was holding a joystick. So, I imagine this glove is incredibly awesome :)

Thats a thing I've always felt VIT (Virtual Immersion Technolgy) needs. The visual and audatory is easy, and with a 360 treadmill you can get good mobility. But physical interaction has been something we've been unable to properly simulate. It doesn't feel natural to have your hands mostly closed and only pressing some buttons to close the virtual hand. Not to mention you can pass through objects. I feel the next step for VR is "simulating limits", ie stopping your movements when you are in contact with something. Instead of walking through a table to get to the door, you now have to walk around it or you can simply lean on it if you feel like it... At this point VR is serving as a way to onboard software and developers into AR. AR hardware is too expensive and limited right now but VR has a large niche following and is good enough for developers to dig into and figure out what works and doesn't work, many findings will apply to AR equally. Unfortunately mainstream audiences are more likely to adopt AR long before VR is accepted by everyone. AR allows people to take baby steps into virtual experiences/products/services and has more real world application because it doesn't take people completely out of their comfort zone and instead makes them feel as if a "virtual thing" has entered the user's world instead of the opposite. The good news for VR fans is that AR hardware is likely to be AR + VR hardware at some point. If your screen is capable of rendering partial images then it's just as likely it can render entire images across the screen eventually.

I think the continuous actuation works like center of mass. While masses (strength of actuator) can be different, when you have multiple masses, the center of mass (the feeling) can be outside of any of the masses (actuators). I think they do the same with the 120 (?) actuators. Our brain feels depending on the distribution and strength, not actual point of "contact".

You might think 120 actuators (there are sure more when taking all sides together) are not much for fine feeling, but think about it like this: 120 actuators, each having for example a strength resolution of 10, you then have a combination posibilities of force of 10^120 = 1,e+120.

I haven't read Ready Player One yet, but I've tried thinking of my own ideas about how to create haptic feedback in virtual reality games ever since I saw Sword Art Online. Of course, I'm no engineer (not yet anyway XD), but I've wondered about how this would be done if I had the technological know-how to implement it. The main flaw in SAO is that they get "fake" feedback through neural feedback, and because of that their muscles atrophy if that persists for too long.

I imagined a sort of pod-like device, kinda like those gimbal rigs that astronauts use to train for 3D rotational motion, except within it was an exoskeleton that you can wear. The exoskeleton would do exactly like what the haptic glove did: resist range of motion based on interactions with the virtual environment. It would generate force against your body when you interacted with objects in the VR, and that'd ensure that any exercise and any skill you did in the virtual world corresponded to your body actually doing it and learning the skills in the real world. Basically like the controls they use in Pacific Rim. So, if you got strong enough to be able to lift a 300lb boulder above your head in the virtual world, you'd be strong enough to be able to do it in real life too.

If those bands they used to resist the finger movements were able to be extended to all the other limbs in the body, they've basically brought my little fantasy VR device to life. If not, they've definitely made a giant leap towards it. Either way, that's pretty amazing.

There was more interesting haptic feedback controllers and tech at GDC 2016. Also It's annoying when they stick a reporter or something like that to try it out because, as a developer, it's hard to get a feel for the tech when the guy is just like "OOOHHH WWOWOOOOWWW IT'S SOOO COOOLLL I CAN FEEL IT." All the questions about it I have remain unanswered as if I just saw a photograph of the glove.
Pretty soon people who actually like face to face interactions with other people will be considered relics.

When I was at GDC last year in San Francisco, there was a company call Ultra Haptics that trying to achieve the same thing but without using a glove. They use a metal board that can project the vertices of the 3D model to your hand then spin it around, so you can feel the shape of the model, and use different type of vibration to project different texture. You can even pick up object in the 3D space and place it on your palm.The main problem I notice is when I place the 3D object on my palm(facing upward), the device had problem projecting it to my hand since they can only project upward with that setup. I guess that is why the main application of their product is in vehicle which allow you to hover your hand and able to turn audio up/down with a virtue button that you can feel. Another application is at hospital elevator which you can select the floor without touching the dirty panels.

It's an interesting intermediate step, for sure. But VR will remain problematic while the body itself is part of the interface, because that system implies your real body has to at least approximate the actions being taken by your virtual one;
And the sheer number of logistical problems that imposes is quite severe.

Consider, for instance, that without very careful prior planning you cannot technically even do something as simple as sitting down in VR without there being problems and even potential safety risks.

haptics and body tracking really are only ever going to be a stopgap in light of this;
we ultimately need a more direct method of control than that...

I find it odd that you find VR stupid. There were a lot of people claiming it would be the future of gaming, which I heavily disagree with, but instead, I feel that VR serves different applications and can open up completely new genres that can coincide with standard gaming.
Look at VR Chat, for example. It's certainly a highly ridiculous game, but the basic premise of it is honestly magical. Being able to almost be in the same room as someone on the other side of the world, talk with them in real time, and even read their body language.. That is an amazing thing. I'm someone with an uncle who lives in Mississippi, and I live in Michigan. My uncle happens to be an awesome person, so I like spending time with him, but we're a few states away. VR could help make that distance gap more bearable.
And that is just an example of the wonders that VR is capable of bringing.
Of course, I don't mean any of this to downplay your own opinion, but I am a quite a bit surprised that you disagree with it so [seemingly] intensely.
Either way, it's cool that you spoke so highly of this haptic feedback glove. I hope the technology becomes even more refined and more widely available soon so that I may be able to try it myself and, say, pet the fur of a virtual dog.
